article.title: Production of a light top-squark pair in association with a light non-standard Higgs boson within the NMSSM at the 13 TeV LHC and a 33 TeV proton collider

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the upper panel of Figure 1 primarily depict?
choices: The mass of the lightest neutralino as a function of the relic density.
The relationship between the Higgs boson mass and the dark matter relic density.
The impact of Z-boson and Higgs-boson exchange on dark matter annihilation.
The allowed parameter space for the NMSSM model based on Planck measurements.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is represented by the green points within the strips in the upper panel of Figure 1?
choices: Parameter spaces that agree with the observed dark matter relic density.
Parameter spaces excluded by direct and indirect dark matter searches.
Parameter spaces consistent with both relic density and dark matter detection experiments.
Parameter spaces favored by the Z3 invariant NMSSM.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the lower panel of Figure 1 illustrate?
choices: The variation of the lightest neutralino mass with its singlet component.
The correlation between dark matter relic density and the singlet component of the lightest neutralino.
The allowed range of the lightest neutralino mass based on various constraints.
The dependence of the dark matter relic density on the lightest neutralino mass and singlet component.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main takeaway from the upper panel of Figure 2?
choices: The masses of the lighter top-squark and lightest neutralino are always degenerate.
The h2-SM scenario favors lighter top-squark masses in the range of 300-1300 GeV.
The allowed mass range for the h2-SM Higgs boson is independent of the lighter top-squark mass.
The branching ratios of the lighter top-squark are insensitive to the mass of the lightest neutralino.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the lower panel of Figure 2 demonstrate about the decay of the non-standard Higgs boson (h1)?
choices: It predominantly decays into a pair of bottom quarks (b¯b) in a significant portion of the allowed parameter space.
The branching ratio for h1 → b¯b is always suppressed compared to other decay channels.
The h1 decay branching ratios are highly sensitive to the mass of the lighter top-squark.
The decay of h1 is irrelevant for the analysis of lighter top-squark phenomenology.
The mass of the lighter top-squark.
The mixing angle between the left- and right-handed top-squarks.
The mass eigenstates of the top-squark.
The contribution of the Higgsino mass parameter to the top-squark mass.
